title: My Florida (Natural Places)
name: My Florida (Natural Places)
description:
A Map by Astrorob

This is Florida. Not Miami, not Orlando, not Bike Week. Florida is more than what we have put here...

properties.name: Everglades National Park
properties.description: Posted by Urbandragon  The river of grass, a slowly moving body of water that flows from Lake Okeechobee to Florida Bay - unique in the world, home to deer, panthers and of course alligators. Beautiful area, several trails for visitors, the Anhinga trail is a boardwalk trail, a fantastic place to see anhingas, cormorants and wading birds during the winter months along with alligators and turtles.

properties.name: Fort Caroline
properties.description: Posted by Astrorob  I first went here in the summer of 1969, shortly after my family returned home. No point in going into the history of the site, since the link will do a better job. Suffice to say, except for a five year period, I have spent at least one day every year (usually around Easter) at the fort. Introduced my godson to it today (25th March \'06). He\'s my legacy, I want him to have this as his.

properties.name: Jupiter Nature Park
properties.description: Posted by Astrorob This little park is located off of US 1 between Jupiter and Juno, Florida. Coastal scrub environment, one of the few areas like it that is still "open" as opposed to "private" (I do so hate "No Trespassing" signs...). I decided to check this place out in the late spring of \'01, forgot to hydrate, and spent the next 24 hours in the hospital due to dehydration! Those trails are actually maze-like; be sure to bring water.

properties.name: Lookout at Theodore Roosevelt Hiking Area
properties.description: Posted by Astrorob Ever stood on the edge of a saltwater marsh and just... listened? During the windy seasons (spring and fall), the marsh grass has a magical quality as the wind whistles through it. Plenty of waterbirds make this and nearby Tiger Creek home. But just go out there and stand... listen... watch...

properties.name: Mandarin Park
properties.description: Posted by AstrorobI lament the passing of the old Mandarin. When I was growing up there in the 1970\'s, it was more like this than the hustle and bustle along SR-13... what they call San Jose Boulevard these days. This gives you a pretty good cross section of forests, from oak paddocks to turkey oak forests. Incidentally, turkey oaks (quercis laevis) is my favorite tree, but is considered a waste tree by some, so too often in the past they\'d be simply removed. Pity, since there is a strange magic in turkey oak forests.

properties.name: Mike Roess Goldhead Branch State Park
properties.description: Posted by Astrorob This is one of those magical places that has remained thankfully unchanged since my childhood. Came here for the first time in May of 1975 with my best friend Craig Buffkin and his family; his birthday. Really loved the place right from the start. There are a number of lakes, a ravine (yes, Florida has ravines), and some of the nicest forests you have ever seen. But look at the satellite image for a second. Look at the spacing of those trees. Most of Goldhead is covered with turkey oaks. When you\'re flying along I-95 south towards Orlando, you\'re seeing woodlands that are artificially thick due to "management". Most forests in Florida would manage themselves, usually through fires. The reason that they are so thick in places is due to letting growth continue in an unnatural fashion. Fires are actually part of the life cycle of forests, God\'s way of keeping things in check. Those turkey oaks (plus some pines) are another example of how Florida should look. Great place. Get there early, stay there late, camp. Walk the trails, enjoy this patch of north Florida.

properties.name: Swim with wild manatee
properties.description: Posted by Jason  Weeki wachi riverThis isn\'t the exact exact location, but the river that connects the weeki wachee spring with the gulf of mexico is home to families of huge gentle amazing manatee (sea cows). You can rent canoes and go upstream to see all kinds of great floridian wildlife, like otter and turtles. Get in the water (chest depp mostly) and go pet the manatee who will mostly just come right up to you. The scars on them are mostly from careless motor boat drivers going too fast and crashing into the not so agile prehistoric animals.

properties.name: The Beach At Big Talbot Island
properties.description: Posted by Astrorob  This is another example of a Florida that once was. As you move south along Florida\'s east coast, the flora changes. This section of the coast line has more in common with beaches northwards into the Carolinas, with stands of oaks almost to the water\'s edge. This beach is truly wonderful, with all that snow white sand. Inland, you\'ll find salt marshes plentiful.

properties.name: This Is Nine Mile Road...
properties.description: Posted by AstrorobNine Mile Road, St. John\'s CountyIn the name of crass commercialization, the road was renamed International Golf Parkway. In reality, it only has anything to do with golf once it crosses Interstate 95. This little stretch of it is how coastal northeast Florida should look. Stunning in the spring time.

properties.name: Tree Hill Nature Center
properties.description: Posted by Astrorob Imagine a nature center of this quality right in the center of the crowded Arlington section of Jacksonville. I first went here in the spring of 1976, and it left an immediate impression; it seemed so out of place, but there it was, tucked into suburbia. I went on to do volunteer work here in 1991. If you get a chance, swing on by and check this wonderful place out. Some of the grandest live oaks you will ever see, ancient grape vines bigger around then your arm, two genuine Florida upland creeks. Take your kids or yourself and see what Florida is really like.
